data.title: Wonderful in so many ways....
data.text: This was recommended to me by my hosts.....I'm so glad I took them up on their suggestion. The house is amazing, and the docents (tour guides) were - as always in America - knowledgable,, witty, and friendly. You won't need to be an architecture or Frank Lloyd Wright fan to appreciate this house, or the stories behind it. Simply marvellous. If you can, go twice..once in daylight and once in the dark (the twilight tours, with music) Not cheap, but definitely worth it.

data.title: Can only go with a group
data.text:
Took taxi there especially.  Then was told I couldn't come in because it was through the Museum tours were organised.  So I found myself stuck in a residential area and no means out until a lovely local lady gave me a ride down the road.  

DON'T GO UNDER YOUR OWN STEAM

owner_response.author: curriermuseum, Director of PR and Marketing at Zimmerman House, responded to this review
owner_response.text: Hello Susan: I'm sorry you didn't get to see the Zimmerman House on your own. Because it is essentially a work of art in our Museum collection, we have to protect it for future generations. That means limiting access to our two daily tours (which leave from the Museum), eight months out of the year. Tickets are available online or by phone. We do make that explicit on our website. Another reason why we do this is due to agreements with the neighborhood and police. The Zimmerman House is located in a residential neighborhood and as you can imagine, they cherish their privacy and quiet. If you have further questions, please feel free to contact us at infocus@currier.org. I hope you do take an opportunity to visit the Museum and the Zimmerman House again.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Great day tour
data.text: Went with a group of women on a tour. Very interesting home and tour. Very well done, worth the admission.

data.title: Enjoyed it....
data.text:
Met the bus at the Currier Museum, and it took 5 minutes for us to get to the house. It is a typical Usonian example, set in a small but beautiful garden. The condition is pristine and totally original. We have visited many Wright houses, and this is not the most overwhelming or impressive. But if you love Wright, it's a must see, as are all his homes! 
The only minor downside was the 2 tour leaders who were, to be "Frank", long winded and not that knowledgeable about Wright, though they knew everything about the house and town history. 
That said, we did enjoy the outing immensely.

data.title: A work of art
data.text:
This is my seventh FLW building and while not as magnificent in scale as Fallingwater it was for our group one of the most emotionally engaging and inspiring. 
The Currier Museum have applied museum standards to the way you interact with the house and you are constantly reminded you are walking in a work of art. 
The conservators have done an outstanding job in preserving this exceptional FLW building. 
They offer stools to sit on if you need them - even if you don't need them do sit down and experience the house from that perspective- it is how it was designed to be enjoyed. 
The Zimmerman house is a must see and congratulations to the Currier for taking it on. 
This is the best $20 you we'll ever spend.

data.title: Worth the trip to Manchester
data.text: We were in NH for a wedding and came to Manchester. I purchased tickets online before we came via the Currier Museum who owns the house. No kids under 7 period. No touching. Great docents.  Truly shows the genius of Frank Lloyd Wright in every inch of the house. Original owners gave the house and an endowment to the museum to care for it. Tour is 90 minutes door- to-door.

data.title: interesting visit
data.text: A must see if you are a fan of Frank Lloyd Wright fan -- tour starts at the museum - some history to the place - then a short bus ride and tour of the house --- cant touch anything in the house as it all is a work of art -- and they provide little booties to cover the shoes -- tour goes in to the house - sees it all -- good hostess to explain - then outside the house tour the grounds - then bus back to museum about 90 mins in all

data.title: Frank Lloyd Wright, Zimmerman House
data.text: Visited with a group of friends after reading "Loving Frank".  Reservations and tickets are done through the Currier Museum and a small bus takes you to the Zimmerman House at your appointed time.  There is also a "drive by" of another nearby Lloyd Wright house.  The staff was very knowledgeable about the house and architecture and also share anecdotal information about both the architect and former residents.  It was a fun and informative trip.  Great follow up to the book about Frank Lloyd Wright.

data.title: Frank Lloyd Wright house
data.text: We are dedicated fans of Frank Lloyd Wright and were thrilled with the opportunity to tour a house that he designed. The tour guide had so much information and lots of insight into Frank Lloyd Wright and the house. We highly recommend this tour.

data.title: Drove by Zimmerman house
data.text: We did this on our own. It would have been better if we did the tour. It was cool and my kids 11, 13 and 19 enjoyed it - we then when to the museum

data.title: Well worth it
data.text: Small group tour of interesting Wright house.  Docents were knowledgeable and tour was very well done.  House is a short minibus ride from the currier museum

data.title: Frank Lloyd Wright architecture at its best
data.text: This house is a superlative piece of  Frank Lloyd Wright architecture. The docents are most knowledgeable as to architecture, FLW's theory and philosophy and present all most entertainingly. Plan your visit for early December when live music is performed within...charming. Reservations must be booked through the Currier Museum

data.title: An agreeable experience
data.text:
First, you need to reserve in advance for a visit. Second, it's a must see. Both guides were knowledgeable and showed their passion for this house. They explained everything in detail and made the 90 minutes visit pass so fast by entertaining you with questions. From outside, this house seems small, but the living room gives it a sence of grandeur, although the 13-inches-off-the-ground furnitures seems to be made for lilliputians. I know Wright wasn't tall, but Zimmerman must have been at least a tad uncomfortable.

Third, this house's ceiling angle remind me of my house, so it felt a little like home.

data.title: Amazing use of space
data.text:
It's hard to believe the Zimmerman house is on only a 3/4 acre lot. The style of the house and its diagonal placement on the lot make the site seem much more spacious.
The living room and bedrooms give one the feeling of being outdoors. The ceilings are a gorgeous cypress. The living room coffee table is in two detachable parts which can be separated to make two smaller tables or added to the kitchen table to make a large one. The bedroom closets are cedar and have built-in pull-out drawers which made all our group envious. My favorite part of the  house is a partial wall in a honeycomb style with many alcoves that hold pieces of colored glass. When the light hits the glass, the effect is magical. I'm not sure how comfortable the house would be, with furnishings 13 inches off the ground; I think a tall person would have his knees around his neck! But the vibe is peaceful and serene. Wright even designed the mailbox, which resembles a tiny temple. The guides were extremely knowledgeable and pleasant.

data.title: Pleasant Tour.  Pam was very knowledgeable and enjoyed giving the tour
data.text:
We toured the Zimmerman house at the end of October 2015.   We left the Currier and Ives Museum with our tour guide Pam for the short drive to the home.  Once we arrived at the house we were told various aspects regarding the outside of the home and them proceeded inside.  Pam explained many of the concepts of the home and while she explained things in detail the tour is not at all boring.  The entire tour takes about 1-1/2 hours and well worth the 20.00 cost.  

Pam grew up in the area and knew of the house growing up.  She now volunteers as a tour guide and it is apparent she really loves the home and giving tours.  The tour is restricted to children 7 years and older and I feel that any child under maybe 12 years old would be bored and my harm some of the homes artifacts and really should not attend.  This is a wonderful tour to get exposure to Frank Lloyd Wrights' architecture and an added benefits for the cost of the tour you are able to visit the museum at no additional charge.

data.title: Big fan of his work
data.text: This house is another one of his masterpieces. This house is smaller than the rest but is lacking no charm. It is quaint and cozy with the same window work and angles he is know for.

data.title: Fantastic tour!
data.text:
I have visited at least 5 FLW tours and this is the best curated and guided experience.  

Both of the guides that I had the pleasure of touring with were knowledgeable and able to cater to a wide variety of guests.  I studied architecture so I am perhaps a bit more critical - but was very impressed.  The property is lovingly cared for.  Book ahead - and make sure to review the special tours that are offered.

data.title: Outstanding!
data.text: This small house packs a lot of punch! Absolutely loved our tour. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and shared additional information about other Frank Lloyd Wright homes which we will make a point of visiting.

data.title: Don't Let the Outside Fool You
data.text: Outside was a bit boring to me, but the inside was beautiful. Visit if you are into art or architecture, or like learning about house design. It's hard to describe the inside... It is just unique. Everything flows together in an open design, and it is decorated very much how it was when the museum acquired the house. The inside and outdoors sort of merge together and it is very light and spacious inside. The landscaping is nice, too.

data.title: Exceptional
data.text: We love Frank Lloyd Wrights work, especially the Usonian houses, and this is a wonderful example beautifully curated with all the furnishings and decorative items of the owners, who had the house designed for them by Wright and lived there for 38 years. The tour of the house was wonderful and informative, but there was so much to admire and take in, we could have happily stayed a lot longer than the allowed time. Many thanks to the tour guide who spent a lot of time chatting with us afterwards and sharing her knowledge and insights.
